message.content:
cs.IT, cs.NI, cs.SY, cs.MA, cs.LG. 

The paper focuses on decentralized updates in multiaccess wireless networks, which suggests that it may belong to the Information Theory (cs.IT) or Networking and Internet Architecture (cs.NI) sub-categories. The use of Markov sources and random-walk state transitions also suggests a potential fit with the Systems and Control (cs.SY) sub-category. The paper also proposes a unified approach for sampling and scheduling, which could be relevant to the Machine Learning (cs.LG) sub-category. Finally, the use case of dynamic channel state information update suggests a potential fit with the Mobile Computing (cs.MA) sub-category.
